newsitem.title: USA: NYCE cotton ends lower, Dec holds major support.
newsitem.headline: NYCE cotton ends lower, Dec holds major support.

text.p: NYCE cotton fell to a fresh contract low for the second consecutive session but managed to recoup some losses and close above the key 70.00 cents a lb level basis December.
Analysts viewed the move as positive and said prices could climb higher Wednesday.
The day's major sellers were the funds, who pressured the market early and then covered short positions amid thin volume late in the session.

One dealer estimated the funds will reveal a 20 percent net short position in Wednesday's speculative/hedge report. "If it's more we could get some bulls back in here," he said, pegging resistance at 71.00 in December.
December cotton settled down 0.42 at 70.30 cents per pound, traded 70.75 to 69.90, a life-of-contract low. The back months finished 0.30 lower to 0.17 firmer.

Prices slid early on the U.S. Department of Agriculture's November supply and demand data. The USDA pegged the 1996/97 crop at 18.594 million 480-lb bales, up 2 percent from October's estimate of 18.189 million bales. Domestic use was flat at 11.0 million bales.
The USDA also raised ending stocks to 4.9 million bales from 4.5 million bales in October.
Internationally, lower estimates in Pakistan, Brazil and Uzbekistan were offset by increases in India, Australia, West Africa and the U.S.
-- Suzanne Rostler, New York Commodities 212-859-1646 (c) Reuters Limited 1996
